title: Global Economy and Markets

sections.title: Macroeconomic Indicators & Market Trends
sections.content:
Global financial markets are influenced by broad economic trends and government policies.

- **GDP (Gross Domestic Product)**: The total value of goods produced and services provided in a country during one year.
- **Inflation**: A general increase in prices and fall in the purchasing value of money.
- **Monetary Policy**: Actions of a central bank to control the money supply and achieve sustainable economic growth.
- **Fiscal Policy**: The use of government spending and tax policies to influence economic conditions.

sections.title: Emerging Markets & Globalization
sections.content:
The global economy is increasingly interconnected.

- **Emerging Markets**: A country that has some characteristics of a developed market, but does not satisfy its standards.
- **Trade War**: A situation in which countries try to damage each other's trade, typically by the imposition of tariffs or quota restrictions.
- **Protectionism**: The theory or practice of shielding a country's domestic industries from foreign competition by taxing imports.
- **Supply Chain**: The network of all the individuals, organizations, resources, activities and technology involved in the creation and sale of a product.

sections.title: Language Focus: Future Perfect & Speculating about Trends
sections.content:
We use the future perfect to talk about actions that will be completed by a specific point in the future.

- **Future Perfect**: 
  - 'By 2030, many emerging markets **will have overtaken** developed ones.'
  - 'The central bank **will have increased** rates several times by the end of the year.'
- **Speculation**: 
  - 'It is **highly likely** that inflation will cool down.'
  - 'There is a **slim chance** of a global recession.'

objectives: Analyze the impact of GDP, inflation, and monetary policy on markets
Discuss the challenges and opportunities in emerging markets
Use the future perfect to make economic predictions and forecasts
